Comment: Unusual opening for me, but nothing that scares me.
Unusual opening for me, but nothing that scares me.
Out of my confort zone, I played...
...knowing that the pawn's defence won't have to be easy.
Oh, that's really brand new to me! Let's have fun!

I assumed that Nd7 was what he was prepared for. Now I am prepared to exchange the B for the N in order to release pressure against d4, that could then be supported by e5. In the meanwhile, I'll had to stand for he attack on the white squares, which I am confident I can do provided I won't lose d4 in the process.
This knight is not actually threatening nothing but c3, and it was foreseen.
The e4 pawn is not defended after my next move, but it is not threatened, either. Even without the bishop, my defences should hold, since the N e5 will be threatened.

No white pawns or lsb in sight to threat my knight, and his is still under threat.

? I should have gone for he queen's exchange, with complete equality. I was confident I could unpin the c pawn and reach a secure c5-e5 solid center.
? I should have gone for he queen's exchange, with complete equality. I was confident I could unpin the c pawn and reach a secure c5-e5 solid center.
White is pressing me hard. I'm not advised to move the e pawn and lose the castling rights.
So I develop the other minor piece, hoping for a better chance. e4 - incredibly - is not threatened yet.
White, correctly, gets more pressure on c6, while I am still far from c5. I hope to force him to play c5 himself, so to block his dsb's action.
Nb6 would unpin the c pawn, supporting a sure c5 from black's side.
Of course, I have to defend c6 first thing.
It holds. My "bet" about the absence of my lsb from the action is costing me a hard game.
? I would say, since it allows my next move. I recognize white's wise judgement in not playing c5, but on the other side the pressure on c6 was his best chance.
I have to be very, very careful, now.
I have to be very, very careful, now.
Finally. But my N has squares to go. And now my e pawn is free.
